songs.title: Astronomy Domine
songs.album: The Piper at the Gates of Dawn
songs.lyrics:
Lime and limpid green
A second scene
A fight between the blue you once knew
Floating down, the sound resounds
Around the icy waters underground
Jupiter and Saturn, Oberon, Miranda and Titania
Neptune, Titan
Stars can frighten

Blinding signs flap
Flicker, flicker, flicker blam. Pow, pow
Stairway scare Dan Dare who’s there?

Lime and limpid green, the sounds surrounds
The icy waters under
Lime and limpid green, the sounds surrounds
The icy waters underground

children: This song was written and composed by Pink Floyd’s original vocalist/guitarist Syd Barrett. It is the first track on their debut album,
The Piper at the Gates of Dawn
. Its working title was “Astronomy Domine (An Astral Chant)”. “Domine” (the vocative of “Lord” in Latin) is a word frequently quoted in Gregorian chants.
At 1:36 in the song, you can hear the sample
Death Grips
used in their song
“I Want It I Need It (Death Heated)”

songs.title: Careful With That Axe, Eugene

children: “Careful With That Axe, Eugene” is the B-side to Pink Floyd’s non-album single, “Point Me At The Sky”.

Although the A-side was not a very noticeable song in the band’s career, “Careful With That Axe, Eugene” became a fan-favourite in the late ‘60s and was played very frequently in the band’s shows for several years.
The studio version was later re-released as part of the
Relics
compilation (1971), but the song also made an appearance in an actual Pink Floyd album, as part of the Live part of
Ummagumma
Here is the live version included in
Ummagumma
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O8OE4gedQuc
The song was also performed as part of the
Live at Pompeii
film in 1972:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b72I7TwsvBE

songs.title: Set the Controls for the Heart of the Sun
songs.lyrics:
Little by little the night turns around
Counting the leaves which tremble at dawn
Lotuses lean on each other in yearning
Under the eaves the swallow is resting

Set the controls for the heart of the sun

Over the mountain watching the watcher
Breaking the darkness
Waking the grapevine
One inch of love is one inch of shadow
Love is the shadow that ripens the wine

Set the controls for the heart of the sun
The heart of the sun, the heart of the sun

Witness the man who raves at the wall
Making the shape of his questions to Heaven
Whether the sun will fall in the evening
Will he remember the lesson of giving?

Set the controls for the heart of the sun
The heart of the sun, the heart of the sun

children: “Set The Controls For The Heart Of The Sun” is a hypnotic paean to the sun which, despite its sci-fi-resounding title, actually borrows a lot from ancient Chinese poetry as its main inspiration. The lyrics to this song, written by Roger Waters, are remarkably elusive and delivered in a murmur, almost unintelligible.
Ref:
http://www.cjvlang.com/Pfloyd/index.html
The studio version of the song is faster-paced than the live one, and while the latter uses the
Farfisa organ
’s sound heavily to give it an oriental feel, the album version features Richard Wright playing the vibraphone, giving it an ambience more inclined to evoke buddhist prayers.
The studio version of the song being on
A Saucerful of Secrets
(1968), a live version was also included on their album
Ummagumma
(1969). It was one of the band’s most performed songs in concert up until about 1972/1973.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W-JI-rdOByk

songs.title: A Saucerful of Secrets
songs.lyrics:
Part 1. Something Else (0:00 - 3:57)
Part 2. Syncopated Pandemonium (3:57 - 7:04)
Part 3. Storm Signal (7:04 - 8:38)
Part 4. Celestial Voices (8:38 - 11:57)

children: This song has the same name of the album it features in. The song has four parts to it.
Part 1. Something Else
Part 2. Syncopated Pandemonium
Part 3. Storm Signal
Part 4. Celestial Voices
There are two common interpretations to what this instrumental piece is supposed to represent.
The first interpretation is the depiction of a battle:
- Part 1 is the set up of battle.
- Part 2 is the battle.
- Part 3 is the view of the dead.
- Part 4 is the mourning of the dead.
The second interpretation is what happends to the mind while tripping on LSD:
- Part 1: vague sensations creep in your stomach and belly, heralding HIS coming.
- Part 2: the trip proper, the brain is turned into a furnace, burning higher and higher and higher.
- Part 3: the ghosts you befriended all night are slowly swept away in the wind and you realize it’s over
- Part 4: stepping outside, you see with the eyes of a newborn child that the bright yellow sun is still shining high up in the blue sky, and the grass is yet a vivid green under your feet
Saucerful Of Secret’s initials spell “SOS”.

songs.title: Sysyphus

children: “Sysyphus” is Richard Wright’s contribution (and opening suite) to the solo effort on Pink Floyd’s double album
Ummagumma
As for all other band members, this roughly half-a-side piece is written, composed and performed solely by Richard Wright himself.
That means, Wright sung each and every vocal track, played all the keyboards (Farfisa, piano, mellotron) drums and various additional instruments that can be heard on it.
“Sysyphus” being a four-part piece, with each part being very distinct, its “lyrics” here are divided in four parts to describe each of those.

The name “Sysyphus” refers to “Sisyphus”, the Greek mythological hero who tried to cheat death by imprisoning Thanatos himself, only to be sentenced to eternal torture in hell: his punishment is to roll a boulder up a mountainside only for it to fall back down and starting over forever.

raw.embed_content: Read “Sysyphus” by Pink Floyd on Genius

That means, Wright sung each and every vocal track, played all the keyboards (Farfisa, piano, mellotron) drums and various additional instruments that can be heard on it.
“Sysyphus” being a four-part piece, with each part being very distinct, its “lyrics” here are divided in four parts to describe each of those.

The name “Sysyphus” refers to “Sisyphus”, the Greek mythological hero who tried to cheat death by imprisoning Thanatos himself, only to be sentenced to eternal torture in hell: his punishment is to roll a boulder up a mountainside only for it to fall back down and starting over forever.

songs.title: Grantchester Meadows
songs.lyrics:
“Icy wind of night be gone this is not your domain”
In the sky a bird was heard to cry
Misty morning whisperings and gentle stirring sounds
Belied the deathly silence that lay all around

Hear the lark and harken to the barking of the dog fox
Gone to ground
See the splashing of the kingfisher flashing to the water
And a river of green is sliding unseen beneath the trees
Laughing as it passes through the endless summer, making for the sea

In the lazy water meadow I lay me down
All around me golden sun flakes settle on the ground
Basking in the sunshine of a bygone afternoon
Bringing sounds of yesterday into this city room

Hear the lark and harken to the barking of the dog fox
Gone to ground
See the splashing of the kingfisher flashing to the water
And a river of green is sliding unseen beneath the trees
Laughing as it passes through the endless summer, making for the sea

In the lazy water meadow I lay me down
All around me golden sun flakes covering the ground
Basking in the sunshine of a bygone afternoon
Bringing sounds of yesterday into my city room

Hear the lark and harken to the barking of the dog fox
Gone to ground
See the splashing of the kingfisher flashing to the water
And a river of green is sliding unseen beneath the trees
Laughing as it passes through the endless summer, making for the sea

children: “Grantchester Meadows” is the second track from the studio disc of the experimental Pink Floyd album
Ummagumma

It was written and performed entirely by Roger Waters. The song features his lyrics accompanied by an acoustic guitar, then a second one, while a tape loop of a skylark chirps in the background throughout the entire song.
At approximately 4:13, the sound of a honking goose is temporarily introduced, followed by the sound of it taking off.
At the end of the track, a flying insect is heard while a manifestly bothered human hunts it down with a newspaper, missing a few strikes and eventually swatting it.
This song was one of several to be considered for but ultimately excluded from the band’s “best of” album,
Echoes: The Best of Pink Floyd

Granchester Meadows are a scenic countryside location in the small town of Granchester, close to Cambridge. Rodger Walters, Syd Barret and David Gilmour all grew up in the Cambridge area, with Gilmour rumoured to still own a property in Granchester.

songs.title: Several Species of Small Furry Animals Gathered Together in a Cave and Grooving With a Pict
songs.lyrics:
Aye an’ a bit of Mackeral settler rack and ruin ran it doon by the haim, ‘ma place well I slapped me and I slapped it doon in the side and I cried, cried, cried
The fear a fallen down taken never back the raize and then Craig Marion fet out wi’ ye Claymore out mi pocket a’ ran doon, doon the middin stain picking the fiery horde that was fallen around ma feet
Never he cried, never shall it get me alive
Ye rotten hound of the burnie crew. Well I snatched fer the blade O my claymore cut and thrust and I fell doon before him round his feet
Aye!
(That was pretty avant-garde, wasn't it?)
A roar he cried frae the bottom of his heart that I would nay fall but as dead, dead as ‘a can be by his feet; de ya ken?
…and the wind cried Mary
Thank you

children: “Several Species of Small Furry Animals Gathered Together in a Cave and Grooving with a Pict” is a track written and performed by Roger Waters from the two-part 1969 Pink Floyd album,
Ummagumma
It is the only Pink Floyd song to feature no instruments besides human voice and mouth noises.

The track consists of several minutes of noises resembling rodents and birds simulated by Waters' voice and other techniques, such as tapping the microphone played at different speeds, followed by Waters' friend and occasional collaborator Ron Geesin providing additional vocals, though his actual contribution is unknown.
The Picts were the indigenous people of what is now Scotland who merged with the Scots.
A small sample of these effects can also be heard at approximately 4:48 on Waters' other track on
Ummagumma
, “Grantchester Meadows”.

songs.title: The Narrow Way
songs.lyrics:
Following the path as it leads towards
The darkness in the north
Weary stranger’s faces show their sympathy
They’ve seen that hope before

And if you want to stay for a little bit
Rest your aching limbs for a little bit
For you the night is beckoning
And now you can’t delay
You hear the night birds calling you
But you can’t catch the words they say
Close your ears and eyes, be on your way

Mist is swirling, creatures crawling
Hear the roar get louder in your ears
You know the folly was your own
But the force behind can’t conquer all you fears

And if you want to stay for a little bit
Rest your aching limbs for a little bit
For you the night is beckoning
And now you can’t delay
You hear the night birds calling you
But you can’t catch the words they say
Close your ears and eyes, be on your way

Throw your thoughts back many years
To the time when love was life with every morning
Perhaps a day will come
When the lights will be as clear as on that morning

And if you want to stay for a little bit
Rest your aching limbs for a little bit
For you the night is beckoning
And now you can’t delay
You hear the night birds calling you
But you can’t catch the words they say
Close your ears and eyes, be on your way

children: “The Narrow Way” is a section on the studio half of Pink Floyd’s fourth album
Ummagumma
. It is a three-part song written and performed entirely by David Gilmour, using multiple overdubs to play all the instruments himself.
It is a three-part composition with only the third part comprising lyrics. These lyrics are the first David Gilmour wrote for Pink Floyd.

raw.lyrics:
Following the path as it leads towards
The darkness in the north
Weary stranger’s faces show their sympathy
They’ve seen that hope before

And if you want to stay for a little bit
Rest your aching limbs for a little bit
For you the night is beckoning
And now you can’t delay
You hear the night birds calling you
But you can’t catch the words they say
Close your ears and eyes, be on your way

Mist is swirling, creatures crawling
Hear the roar get louder in your ears
You know the folly was your own
But the force behind can’t conquer all you fears

And if you want to stay for a little bit
Rest your aching limbs for a little bit
For you the night is beckoning
And now you can’t delay
You hear the night birds calling you
But you can’t catch the words they say
Close your ears and eyes, be on your way

Throw your thoughts back many years
To the time when love was life with every morning
Perhaps a day will come
When the lights will be as clear as on that morning

And if you want to stay for a little bit
Rest your aching limbs for a little bit
For you the night is beckoning
And now you can’t delay
You hear the night birds calling you
But you can’t catch the words they say
Close your ears and eyes, be on your way
